Fields.DialogueText: Captain - it's good to see you!
I'm sorry we haven't had much time to talk. It's been busy.
I can see that. The guns look pristine, the deck is spotless, the engines are purring - this is a tightly-run ship.
And, of course, your combat record speaks for itself.
Well, so does yours.
You've met Lieutenant Justice? I've basically appropriated her as my aide-de-camp - this is the only time you'll ever hear Army lingo pass my lips, by the by - and I hope you'll let that stand.
I like having my very own assistant coach on hand.
Good to meet you, Captain.
And you, Lieutenant. I assume being an "assistant coach" suits you?
Sure. And you eventually learn to tune the gridiron metaphors out, Captain.
I'm going to pretend I didn't hear that, Lieutenant.  Are you a football person, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: Oh, yeah.
Enh.
Please don't tell me you mean American-style.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, we're gonna get along just swell.
... We'll work on that.
Oh, are you one of those people who thinks "football" means "soccer?" We'll work on that.
Listen, I come bearing orders. I want to get the officers together at the earliest possible opportunity to...
I know what it means when a Belle gets that look in her eye.
I'm sure you do. Justice, if you want to get to your station before the alarm sounds, you should probably start running.
@BATTLE
If you'll excuse me, Captain?
Permission to start running granted.
Respectfully, Captain, I think I hate this. It feels like busy work.
This is coming from a woman who has the floor of the mess hand-scrubbed twice a day, Captain. And then hand-toweled-off just to be sure it's safe.
That's not busy work, that's creative endurance training. You're just grumpy because I expect the officers to pitch in.
But *this* sounds like a milk run from a bunch of admirals who think I need training wheels after my stay in dry dock. And nuts to that!

Fields.MenuText: There are no milk runs in this war. Trust me on that.
Fastest way to lose training wheels is to show you can ride the bike.
There was a picture of you on fire on the cover of Time Magazine. They may be a little skittish.

Fields.DialogueText: Yeah, but still...
Some might say that the fastest way is just to break them off the bike yourself.
That was a picture of me after we beat Vanity and Sin and ran five hundred nautical miles round trip to rescue a pack of destroyers. I wouldn't think the lesson there is that I'm fragile!
Look, you've been to Midway on I don't know how many exercises, it's essential to American long-term plans for the Morgana War in the Pacific, and it's a natural base for patrols.
There's no ship better suited to go on this run, and I think you know it.
But the Morganas are supposed to be thickest up around the Aleutians, right? I've been there too! Shouldn't I be just as much a natural for a northern job?
Listen, if it's as quiet as you're afraid it's going to be, I'll request a new assignment. But let's go see what's there before we write it off as beneath your notice.
Ugh. Fine!
She means, "Ugh. Fine, Captain."
If they're sidelining me because some idiot general has a bright idea about launching bombers from Alaska *grumble grumble*...
So... uh... how are you settling in, Captain?
@BATTLE
Captain, we're making good time... but I think it might be a good idea to slow down a little.
Turbine troubles?
Bite your tongue!
No, it's just... even by Belle standards, I've got pretty good ears for Morganas. Somebody's lurking around here, and I want to get `em before they can make for Hawai'i.
With your permission, obviously.
Permission granted, also obviously. Can you give us a course to intercept?
Not... yet.
Right. Plan B is to draw them to us.  Any noise we make out here will carry for miles.
Wait. Are they really dumb enough to just come if you call?

Fields.MenuText: They usually have an advantage in numbers, in fairness.
I know. It's hilarious.
Not all. But usually they're either half-crazed or really arrogant.

Fields.DialogueText: Go figure.
Given the hour, that'll probably mean night fighting... and this is as good a time as any to see what we can do.
I've seen the reports on your night battle exercises. As long as we're not looking at a pack of Vanities I like our chances.
... What do you think about Swede Larson?
Pardon?
I'm just trying to figure out if I like you as much as I think I do.
@BATTLE
Huh. This may not be a total waste of time after all.
There are more of them around?
Just at the edge of my detection range, buzzing around. They're like mosquitoes.

Fields.MenuText: Just going back a step - patrol orders are never a waste of time.
Doesn't seem organized enough to be a major threat to Hawai'i. So far, at least.
Right. Time to get swatting.

Fields.DialogueText: Sure, Captain. *big wink*
Agreed. But it's strange.
Luckily, I happen to have a great number of 335 pound swatters stuffed with high explosives. It's amazing how it all works out.
Right. Let's go hunting.
@BATTLE
Listen, Captain, I need to see to repairs and shout at a few dozen goldbrickers-
Plus, technically, there's the INPF after-action report, the ammunition inventory, the turbine checklist, the-
You have to learn to forge my signature, Lieutenant.
I really don't, ma'am.
Anyway, Captain, when that's done I hope you'll have a few minutes. I don't know if you noticed, but-

Fields.MenuText: These guys came from the southwest, like the last batch.
Do your duties and walk me through it later. There are fires burning now.
Let's go back to that "forging signatures" thing for a second.

Fields.DialogueText: Exactly.
Understood, Captain!
Yeah, you must have heard that wrong. Ears still ringing from the guns, I bet. We'll talk later!
We'll talk later.
Nothing on the radio, of course.
Yeah, it's that kind of war. But I've been reviewing all the intelligence that's been shared with us over the last couple of weeks...
And?
There's a Sherlock Holmes story where the decisive clue is a dog that doesn't bark because the intruder isn't an intruder.
"Silver Blaze."
Yes. You read a lot. Shush.
What are you getting at, Captain?
Maybe nothing - but the British were seeing moderately high Morgana activity around the Tarawa Atoll for several days, and then it all dropped off before they could send reinforcements.
So they stocked up and moved east?

Fields.MenuText: It's just a guess.
If so, the question is whether it's an instinctive migration - like insects - or if they have a plan.
I mean, it'd be great if they all just sank while nobody was watching, but...

Fields.DialogueText: I don't think this is the only possible answer - but Morgana activity seems to have been normal all the way from Peru to San Pedro when last we heard. I don't think these guys are from the Americas.
So, what d'you think? Take a more southerly route to Midway Atoll? Do a little reconnaissance?
I think it's-
Hang on.
I need to go sound general quarters, Captain. And, yes, they're coming from the south again.
@BATTLE
I still say this whole mission was meant to be a waste of our time, by the way.
... Are you having the crew disassemble and reassemble fake naval rifles?
You're changing the subject - but, yes. I made them all to scale out of scrap metal. You wouldn't know it to look at me, but I'm a wonder in a machine shop.
I'm impressed. But is this really the best use of their time?
Oh, don't worry. They're supposed to be off-duty. All the on-duty crew are doing their jobs.
So they're... doing this for fun?
For the love of learning, Captain. For the satisfaction of a job well done.
Right. So, really, is it bribery, blackmail, or brute force?
Aw. It's adorable you think I'd use just one of the tools in the Belle box. Keep on underestimating me, Captain - it makes for a fun trip.
Uh-huh.
Listen, Captain, everybody knows Morganas are close - nobody's just going to relax. Why not get `em building skills that could save their lives?

Fields.MenuText: You haven't heard me order you to stop.
As long as it's voluntary.
Don't go overboard. The crew tires out faster than you do.

Fields.DialogueText: Ain't that the truth?
I'll keep that in mind!
This is true. Thanks for that, Captain.
Have you-
There they are.
Morganas?
Yeah. Over there. Your eyes probably can't... never mind, just trust me.
@BATTLE
Hello, Captain. I'm delivering some paperwork from Pensacola - if you have any desk space?
It might have to be a neat stack on the floor, I'm afraid. My desk seems to have been colonized by charts.
I can just throw these over the side and tell her she has to do them again if you like.
What? It'd be the end of me, but it would be hilarious.
I've been meaning to ask - I'm assuming you haven't spent your life in military service?
No, Captain. That's a safe assumption. I was doing my bit in the civil service - but I'm one of those cases where I have a rank because the Belle says I do and nobody wanted to argue.
Y'know, they pick captains who win tons of battles, so I think a lot of the top brass figure they have magic greatness-detecting powers.

Fields.MenuText: Trust me, I've argued with some of those admirals. They don't think that at all.
Good thing you and I know better.
I mean, I think you could make a pretty strong case...

Fields.DialogueText: Pensacola would've had to fight for you, and your last commanding officer would've had to back her up. And it wouldn't have been easy.
Let's not spread it around, though. I like that my dad's wondering if I'm actually a military genius.
For you, sure.
So, how did you end up onboard?
Oh, my little brother was a petty officer when the Morganas... really, when the killing started.
I think it was... what, thirty-two hours between the start of the Morgana attack and Pensacola's awakening?
Something like that. They say she's the ship that wouldn't die, and that's totally fair - but it was her crew that refused to give up first. She says they saved her more than she saved them.
And your brother? Was he...?
Oh, he survived. Um... lost a leg. Pensacola was awake by the time he was wounded, and she cauterized it. Saved his life.
So... um... I was in California anyway when she finally made it back to San Diego. And when I heard that women were personally applying to Belles for combat duty... it seemed like the thing to do.
And I just told her who I was, and that I would work like you wouldn't believe. And she kind of made a project out of me, I guess.
And a lieutenant.
Yeah, that... I didn't expect that. But I have a degree and I had a pretty good job with Governor Olson's office, so she said it was more like a lateral transfer than anything else.
I don't know. She probably just figured I'd do more damage if I were a petty officer.

Fields.MenuText: I could see it.
I think there's a decent chance she wanted you cleared to read reports so she doesn't have to.
Just make sure you repay her trust in you. It's a rare thing.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, Captain.
No, don't believe it. I give her grief, but nobody works harder than her. I mean, nobody.
Okay. Anyway, put those papers down over-
*ALARM*
Just put them anywhere. I have new plans.
@BATTLE
So, Captain - our friendly navigator just told me about this new course you have planned.
Minor detour.
Actually, I do believe it's more than fifteen hundred miles from Midway to the Marshall Islands.
Huh. Interesting point of trivia. I'll remember that.
Captain?
You worried we're going to run out of fuel, ship's Belle?
I'm just worried you're going to get fired just as I'm starting to like you.

Fields.MenuText: I won't. Probably.
Ah, you liked me at least a day or two ago.
I think it's important.

Fields.DialogueText: There really isn't anyone we can talk to on Midway Island. Pan Am isn't doing flights there anymore, the hotels have been closed - as a source of intelligence it's of limited short-term use.
We have the British intelligence. We keep getting signs of Morgana activity further south, the Marshalls are further south - I think it's worth pushing the engines to see what we can learn.
You know I am. Plus it gives us more time to talk about football!
Oh, God, no.
I think you mean, "I welcome this chance to learn from people with a wider knowledge of the world about its most perfect game."
I don't think so, ma'am. I'm pretty sure I meant something else entirely.

Fields.MenuText: Suck it up, Lieutenant.
I'll just leave you two to it, shall I?
It still kills me that you're talking about American football that way.

Fields.DialogueText: See? This is why the Captain's in charge.
Please don't.
Don't make me break out my itemized list of why football is better than soccer, Captain. I've got it. It's real.
I- okay, wait. We're not alone.
Let's take that as a sign we're on the right track.
@BATTLE
Aren't the Japanese meant to be... somewhat touchy about foreign ships around there?
If we're driving off Morganas on behalf of the League, I don't expect trouble. Assuming Pensacola is willing?
Hey, Captain. Have you looked over the side lately?
No - I've been in down below all morning. You know your boilers seem to be running hot?
They're boilers. They're supposed to be hot. Seriously, look.
If there's some kind of blockage that's keeping the hot water from...
... That's a lot of dead fish.
Yeah, it is.

Fields.MenuText: There've been other die-offs reported. Weird temperature zones aren't good for ecosystems.
Just when I think the Morganas have run out of ways to make the crew uneasy...
Great. Now I'm hungry.

Fields.DialogueText: Great. We can add crimes against nature to the list.
I find the trick is to work them too hard to notice.
I noticed that.
I mean, they're probably poisoned, but I could grab one for you if you're feeling adventurous.

Fields.MenuText: No, thanks.
Don't tempt me. I have a bad history with stupid dares.

Fields.DialogueText: You're still tracking a local Morgana group, right?
Yeah. They'll be in visual range soon, I think.
If you think you have time, get a few fish and a sample of the water. If there are active contaminants out here, we need to know about it.
"Hey, Pensacola, that water could be toxic. Could you reach in and grab me some?"
You're right. I should've said "please."
Heh.
@BATTLE
I don't like those clouds.
I don't like that we're still seeing dead fish.
Thankfully, I can generate enough liking to cancel both of you out, because I am a very positive person.
No, you're not.
Yes. That was a lie. Captain, ma'am, I have... preliminary fish biopsies, if you're in the mood.

Fields.MenuText: What kind of mood would that be?
Yeah, let's get it over with.
Pensacola? Morganas far enough out?

Fields.DialogueText: I wouldn't want to speculate, Captain.
I think we have time for summary, at least. Have you done the reading, Lieutenant?
I hope that goes without saying, ma'am.
Short version: gills are unobstructed, no sign of chemical burns. The phrase that leaps out is "organ rupture."
That's definitely a phrase that leaps, yes.
Sorry, Captain - Pensacola? Ma'am? Is something wrong?
Captain, I think I'm picking up something that isn't a Morgana - and probably in need of rescue. I need to get to the bridge and lay in a new course if you-
Go.
Right. Boilers may be running hot again for a while!
@BATTLE
What was she doing all the way out here? The Japanese know better than to have ocean liners tooting around unguarded these days, don't they?
You see those grooves in the hull? I bet they were from some kind of cord. And those rents were from... something like harpoons. I think she was probably just captured and dragged.
I want to blow something up.
Hey, are you-
I'm fine. It's just... trust me, knowing her crew and her passengers were dying and not being able to wake up and do anything about it? It's not fun.

Fields.MenuText: I wouldn't think so.
Would she have been aware of it, you think?
We'll get the Morganas that did it, you know. Maybe we already have.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't know. I've never been a passenger ship - maybe if you weren't built to fight it doesn't... nag at you the same way.
Too late for her.
You were on the human side of one of these messes when the war started, right?
Word around the fleet is that you were on a ship that hadn't woken, got knocked off, and if Recruit hadn't been there - somehow - you would've...
Something like that. And a lot of the people I was with... well, they weren't as lucky.
And, for the record, I never blamed the ship I was on before for that. Not for one second. None of us would.
I sometimes think all you Belles are waking up because your sailors love their ships too much to let go of you when the Morganas come.
... I also like French fries. Couldn't eat French fries when I was just a sleeping boat. Had to wake up for that.
Yeah. Okay. French fries, then the love of your crews. That's what got you all up.
And the clothes. I mean, look at me! I couldn't dress like this when I was... Hang on.
They're close?
Yeah. Let me sound the alarm - I'll meet you on the bridge.
@BATTLE
But it's hard to be sure without survivors.
Hey, Captain! Think fast!
Think fast about... oh.
Fourth down! The Captain's fast approaching the end zone - the daring and startlingly beautiful quarterback is about to pass - the whole game is on the line!
Inventory updates for you to sign, ma'am.
GAH!
Apparently we're eating more carrots than anyone expected.
Lieutenant, you're interrupting a very important targeting exercise.
Sorry, ma'am. I mistakenly thought that you were about to start pelting the Captain with footballs.
How many footballs do you see, Lieutenant?
One, ma'am.
You will concede that it therefore follows I couldn't be pelting the Captain with multiple footballs.
You have strange Belle powers, ma'am. I assume you could pelt the Captain with all kinds of things I can't currently see.

Fields.MenuText: I really don't like the way this conversation is going.
Lieutenant, I was all set to enjoy a few friendly passes, and now you've made it weird.
I'll just leave you two to it.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm sure it would all be in the service of improving her targeting, Captain.
It would! But that's beside the point.
See? See?!
*sigh*
Ma'am, if I might make a personal observation...?
It's probably a terrible idea, but go ahead.
Captain, I don't know if you've been around long enough to notice, but I think that football only comes out when Pensacola is-
If you say "nervous," I will bean you with it, Lieutenant.
- preoccupied with concerns the human crew might not be aware of.
Is that true, ship's Belle?
Universally, no. I mean, I like playing games when I have the free time...
Which is basically never.
Hang on. Morganas. You need to get to the bridge, Captain.
Damn. We'll get back to this later!
Whoopie.
@BATTLE
Thanks for inviting me down, Captain. Nice to see what you've done with your quarters. It's...

Fields.MenuText: Homey?
Austere?
A disaster area?

Fields.DialogueText: Enough to show me you're comfortable here. I like that.
Comes with the job, I suppose.
I wasn't going to mention it, but... are you used to having a maid or something?
A little chaos is the sign of a creative mind, Pensacola.
Hold that thought. Is that pile of socks moving?
Let's assume it isn't.
So, the other day, I noticed that you didn't exactly disagree when Lieutenant Justice said something was bothering you.
I won't lie. I didn't like having to sink that ocean liner. It's been - the whole thing has been nagging at me.
I didn't like it either. But the engines were past saving, and we couldn't tow her with us.
Oh, I know. I'm not saying it was the wrong thing to do, Captain. We couldn't let them just... have her.
Y'know, we never found a log. Or charts. It seems like almost everything that wasn't bolted down on that boat was gone.
Maybe she wasn't crewed at all when the Morganas got her. Could be the Japanese government was in the middle of converting her to wartime use and the Morganas got lucky.
We can ask if we ever make radio contact with anyone again.
"If?" You *are* down.
Slip of the tongue, Captain. I was just distracted by some bad news.
More of them?
Yeah. If you want to get to the bridge before the klaxon sounds...
@BATTLE
I would've expected to have seen some of the Ratak Chain by now.
I mean, I *believe* that we're on course...
... but with a battle a day, and with the sky cloudy most nights, and with weird magnetic fields screwing our compasses around, we could've gotten turned around.
And the radio silence is making me nuts. I don't even understand it - it's not like I spent my whole career around cities. I should be fine with the quiet!
But there's nothing to *listen to* apart from the Morganas just whispering around the edges.
... What time is it?
About three in the morning. Sorry, did I wake you?

Fields.MenuText: Yes.
Not if this is actually a weird dream.
... It's about time I was getting up anyway.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, for what it's worth, Morganas are close enough that I'll have to sound the alarm within the hour anyway.
Mm. Great.
... You said something about Morgana whispering?
Yeah. It's fairly constant, actually.
It's possible they're doing it intentionally, you know.
Using your senses against you, trying to get into your head? Most of them aren't smart enough, but...
The one I hear most often is Despair. Or one of the Despairs - I still don't know how that works.
Yeah. That one. Okay.
I'm not scared of her. I mean, she's just a cruiser. We blow through versions of her all the time.
Yeah, but she doesn't want to destroy - not the really alert versions. She wants to own.
Listen, let me get dressed. I'll meet you on the bridge, we'll sink whoever's stupid enough to try to target us, and then we'll talk this through.
Nah, there's nothing to talk through. I mean, I'm all for sinking the Morganas, but everything else is just stupid nerves. I'm sorry I bothered you with it.
Uh-huh.
Aren't you going to get dressed?
I'm waiting for you to leave.
Oh. Right.
Darn.
Yeah, yeah. I'll see you on the bridge. And then we'll have a nice talk about knocking before entering.
@BATTLE
Captain? They're trying something new.
That's not something I like to hear. What's going on?
Okay, my best guess is that Bikar Atoll is just a few miles out in the mist somewhere over there.  Call it two o'clock.
Right.
And I think the Morganas have something on it or near it that's pumping out Morgana Mist. Extra-lethal stuff.
I'm suppressing it, so you and the crew don't just die, but it's taking a lot of concentration - and the whispering's getting louder. I think an attack is pending.

Fields.MenuText: So it's a trap?
Okay, you're going to have to walk and chew gum at the same time.
Huh. Well, it's the end of my shift, so I'll just let the next guy handle it.

Fields.DialogueText: That's one word for it.
I hate the taste of gum.
Noted.
Don't make me laugh right now, Captain.
I think... I think this is a probe of my defenses.
They know we're relatively isolated out here and want to see what works on you? Damn, maybe they *are* getting smarter.
Are you going to be okay with the usual fire support and so on? Or should we try to run?
Oh, I'm not running, Captain. I just thought you should know what's going on.
Good. Then let's find something to shoot.
@BATTLE
*KNOCK*
You're learning! Come on in.
What do you mean I'm- oh.
Sorry. I never did apologize for barging in on you the other night, did I?

Fields.MenuText: I think you did, actually. It's fine.
I can't remember either. Things have been hectic.
You apologized. I'm not sure I ever said it was accepted.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh. *Is* it accepted?
Only because I can't think of anything I need to guilt you into doing right now.
You can say that again.
Well... seriously, I *am* sorry. I wouldn't have done that to any other crew member, but I have this weird habit of thinking of you like you're almost another Belle.
Excuse me?
I'm serious! Terrible sleep habits, unnatural awareness of things going on around the ship - honestly, sometimes Morganas even talk to you.
I really think I sometimes forget you're human.

Fields.MenuText: I promise I am.
I'm more proud of that than I probably ought to be.
Well, that's... unsettling.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll try to keep it in mind.
It was meant as a compliment! Mostly.
Probably.
So... what can I do for you, Captain?
Right. There's no easy way to say this - I'm wondering if we're in a trap.
More so than usual, you mean?
Yeah. Listen, if the Morganas are paying attention, I would think that one thing they could predict about me - as a captain - is that I take my investigative role seriously.
It's my job to find out what these things are doing here, right?
So if you wanted to get my attention, maybe you'd make a point of scattering Morganas to the south of our known location, and have them lead us like a trail of breadcrumbs.
Once we're far enough away from the Neutrality Fleet's Pacific assets to be vulnerable, you start disorienting the lead Belle with whispers and navigational oddities.
Then we get to Bikar, where they've set up that poison platform we blew up.
Right. Now we've got a good chunk of the crew showing signs of mist sickness - minor signs, happily, but still - and we still haven't made radio contact with Majuro. Or any local human traffic.
It's our duty to keep investigating - we can't exactly give up on the Marshall Islands - but...
But you think we're right where they want us.
I don't think we're there yet. I think we're *going* right where they want us.
Does that sound plausible to you? Or is Despair getting to me?
... I hate to say it, Captain, but we have Morganas incoming. Maybe that answers your question.
@BATTLE
Give it a few seconds, Captain. It's the first radio signal we've received in weeks, and it repeats.
Distress signal?
I mean, it causes *us* distress.
Yeah, you can tell from the distortion it's a Morgana voice. It isn't pleasant.
Any second. I don't know if you can feel it - to me it's like a static charge that-
*static*my hand, know me, and*static*
Some kind of code, you think?
*static*all you need*static*
Captain? You okay?
Yeah.
"Take my hand, know me, and you will persist. I'm all you need. Now sleep."
Oh-kaaaay?
It's Despair. It's what she said to me at the very start of the war.

Fields.MenuText: She's not very original.
She knows it's me.
I can't tell you how good it feels to watch her sink.

Fields.DialogueText: Yeah. Well, it's not *just* you.
I'm sensing Morganas approaching, Captain. But not the source of this signal.
And it's not like it worked for her the first time.
It's okay. Let's just get rid of the ones we can reach.
@BATTLE
Anything to report?
Visibility's garbage. Electrical systems are erratic. We've got nothing to navigate by, and if I weren't a Belle I think we'd've been in serious risk of sailing into shallow waters and getting stuck.
And the Despair broadcast?
Getting louder. Still sending that message to you on the radio - I don't know how Recruit made her shut up back in the day.

Fields.MenuText: She was close enough to shoot back then.
I know I don't have to tell you not to let her get to you.
Hey. You think there's going to be an Army-Navy game next year?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, hell, yes. And Navy's gonna run away with it.
Back atcha, Captain.
Must've been nice.
*BOOM*
What the-?
I don't - let me listen!
They're coming from starboard! Asphyxiation's ahead of the pack, I think! More behind her!
Dammit! Sound general quarters!
@BATTLE
*KNOCK*
Enter!
Hey, Captain. Do you have a minute?
Maybe even five. How is it out there?
Nice night, apart from the mist, the blackouts, the strange voices, the not knowing where the hell Majuro is...
You want to sit down?
... Okay. Thanks.
I didn't actually mean on the floor, but... what the hell.

Fields.MenuText: Scoot over.
You're making me feel grateful for my chair.
I hope you don't mind if I keep standing.

Fields.DialogueText: Deal. Make yourself comfortable.
It's a good one. Got it for a song in San Diego.
Not at all. I hear it's good for your heart.
So. I think it's safe to say there's a Morgana infestation around the Marshall Islands - at least in the east - and they may be specifically on a mission to get at us. Or me, specifically.
And I'm not doing a great job of keeping it from happening.
You've won every single fight we've been in and you're a wizard at conserving fuel. If you weren't awake, we'd all be dead.
"Not dead" isn't enough, Captain. "Not dead" isn't the mission.
Technically, the mission is to go to Midway and back.
Heh.
I'm sure you were right, by the way. I'm sure it *was* meant as a milk run. You were the hero ship on the magazine cover - it would've been a PR disaster if I'd immediately gotten you sunk.
Would've been pretty embarrassing for you, too.
Nah. I'd've blamed it all on Lt. Justice.
Oh, sure. It's why I keep her around.
... So. We need a plan.
Sorry, Captain. We have to sink some Morganas first.  There's a group that's just entered my hearing range.
It's okay. Whatever the plan turns out to be, sinking them is part of it.
@BATTLE
I hate this plan. Lieutenant, please make a note that I hate the plan.
I have. You can initial it in my notes if you think it's really important.
Don't encourage her, Lieutenant.
Captain, encouraging me is basically her only job.
And, also, I hate this plan.
My only job? Respectfully, ma'am, in the last twelve hours I've-

Fields.MenuText: Not on the bridge, people.
Do we have popcorn?
Pensacola. Focus.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, Captain. We do. I know that because I did a special inventory of food supplies at three o'clock in the morning.
Sorry, Captain.
*sigh*
Listen, I know the sisterly back-and-forth is good for your morale, but we need to get on the same page here.
Pensacola, be clear - do you hate the plan because you don't think it can work, or are you expressing frustration before agreeing to do it?
Okay, playfulness aside, it's a risk to my crew, and not the kind of risk I like.
I know, but check my logic. The core Morgana force here is keeping its distance, keeping us isolated, and trying to wear us down. And they're manipulating atmospheric conditions and pumping out gas.
I have to assume that her endgame is to push us until something breaks, then swoop in for the kill.
Right.
So it seems to me that the fastest way to resolve the situation is to act like we're in worse shape than we are.
Slow down, fake engine trouble, stage some "accidental" fires, start making our radio broadcasts more desperate. Make our defenses as sloppy as we dare.
They think they know *me*, but they can't know what kind of endurance you bring to the table. It shouldn't be hard to convince them that the strain is breaking you when it *would* break other ships.
Sure. And I like the flattery. But, Captain, it's not going to be a matter of slowing down for three hours and getting the fight we want.
If I play sick, what they're going to do is send in the heaviest Morganas they can find. Cruisers at a minimum, and probably worse.
Yeah.
We're going to take a beating. Whatever ship is organizing this doesn't want to engage directly - she's not going to come for us herself until she thinks battleships have all but killed us.
Yeah.
But you're USS Pensacola. I know that sounds glib, but everything I've seen over the past few weeks tells me we can take the hits.
... This is true.
And the point is to take no more damage than we usually do, right? Just to make it look worse?
Ma'am, there's no crew in this fleet with more experience taking things apart and putting them back together under duress. And we can do realistic evacuation drills on a dime.
Give me a day to figure it out and choreograph it, and I promise I can make it work.
... Actually, we're about to be under attack. So you have however long the battle takes to figure out how to make it look like we're barely alive at the end of it. Assuming the Captain agrees?
The Captain does. Thank you for the trust, Pensacola.
Same to you. I think.
@BATTLE
You think Despair's behind all this?
I don't think we're going to know until we sink a random Morgana and suddenly our instruments can tell us which direction is north.
To you it's instruments. To me, it's like one of my senses has gone squirrely. Not one of the top ten senses, sure, but-
Top ten?
I have a lot of systems, Captain.
Right.
How're you holding up?
Faking critical engine damage isn't exactly hard work. And Justice and her teams are doing all the heavy lifting with the "round-the-clock" repairs - I just have to harmlessly misfire every so often.
It's actually the most free time I've had since the war started.

Fields.MenuText: So, you hate it.
Have you been tossing the ol' football around?
Don't worry. You'll be working overtime soon enough.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, Captain. You really get me.
No, unfortunately. I need to come across as stressed out, not bored.
I thought throwing the ball *is* what you do when you're stressed.
But it's not supposed to look like it.
You may be overthinking this.
Oh, I hope so.
The paperwork alone-
I'm begging you, don't go there.
Hang on. A lot of my electricals are about to go down again.
Intentionally, or-?
No. Not this time. They're coming.
@BATTLE
*KNOCK*
Come in!
So, I'm impressed. You were literally tossing and turning hard enough to wake up the ship.
*YAWN* Sorry about that. You get to thinking about strategy at three in the morning and it's pretty hard to stop.
No, I know. Actually, that's kind of why I'm here to talk to you - this isn't really a conversation I can have with Justice.
Okay.
You've... probably picked up on the fact that those thirty-two hours between when the Morganas first attacks and when I was able to fight back were bad. For me. For my head.
I'm not going to crack up on you or anything...

Fields.MenuText: I know.
You'd damn well better not!
Is this about our strategy here? Is there a problem?

Fields.DialogueText: Thanks.
Please. USS Pensacola, remember?
Not a major one, Captain. Don't worry.
I'm just wondering if I can ask a favor. And it's a weird one.
Ask.
The plan is, I'm going to pretend to be really hurt after the next battle, right? And that means I can't be very active as a Belle. The Morganas need to think I'll almost dormant.
You and the crew will mostly be running the ship like I'm asleep again, until we're ready to spring our trap.
I'll keep the crew safe, Pensacola. You have my word.
Well, yeah, duh. We wouldn't be doing this if I didn't trust you!
No, I'm just... can you talk to me sometimes? Even when I'm not there? I think that might make the waiting easier.

Fields.MenuText: Of course.
You just think it'll be funny to have the crew convinced I'm talking to myself.

Fields.DialogueText: No comment.
Heh. Yeah. Of course I'll do it.
Thank you, Captain. Very much.
... But now you should probably get to the bridge.
@BATTLE
And that's the story of my twelfth birthday.

Fields.MenuText: I still have the scars.
Nobody back home ever asked if I knew how to dance again.
I told you I was a quiet kid.

Fields.DialogueText: You probably know the mist is getting worse. No signs of severe sickness in the crew, but visibility's terrible. We've beefed up the watch schedule, but it's not the same without you.
Captain? Are you... busy?
Just taking in the slightly toxic sea air, Lieutenant. Is there news?
Oh-kay. We're having some difficulties with steering, Captain. As in, apparently we're going in circles. The folks in the bridge are wondering if we should cut the engines and check the propellers.
Huh. Was that on your scheduled list of mechanical problems?
It was... but not for another six or seven hours. Pensacola must be getting bored in hibernation.
... Or she knows we're being observed. Lieutenant, get to the bridge and make it known - quietly - that an attack may be imminent.
Oh. Oh, that's clever. Will do, Captain!
Obviously, Pensacola, I'm sorry if listening to my childhood stories just gave you some kind of seizure.
@BATTLE
Captain? You think this is it?
I hope it is. That last battle, they threw battleships at us. They have every reason to think we're dead in the water, and it's been almost forty-eight hours since we've heard a peep from Pensacola.
Morganas don't generally have a lot of patience. I think it's reasonable to assume that they'll swoop in to finish us off - and maybe gloat - sooner rather than later.
Plus, we've finished off over a dozen Morgana clusters in the last couple of weeks.  I know our reports on their Pacific activites are out of date, but still....
Yeah, hopefully they're running out of reserves to bring against us.

Fields.MenuText: If we're really lucky, they've already pulled away raiding parties from Majuro and its neighbors.
Of course, hopes only get us so far in this war.
Now, let's just hope we can turn the engines back on when we need them.

Fields.DialogueText: Fingers crossed.
True enough.
Don't worry, Captain. Pensacola has to know I'd haunt her forever if I got killed because she was too lazy to move.
*sigh*
Everything okay, Lieutenant?
... I've run out of paperwork.
Can you... say that louder so that Pensacola can hear it?

I need something to work on, Captain! I'm a really task-oriented person, and it's how I deal with stress, and I don't have anything to do. I've tried to volunteer with the sham engineering crews, but-
*ALARM*
I guess you're in luck.
@BATTLE
Pensacola, if you're listening, I'm not just saying that.
Somebody get me a damage report, now! As long as Pensacola's running quiet, we have to pick up the slack and remember how to do our jobs, people!
Lieutenant, find me-
Captain?
What?
Look outside. Is it just me, or the mist... is the mist breaking up?
Well, I'll be-
Lieutenant, check in with the radio room - see if we're still getting Despair on every frequency!
We're not.
Ma'am!
And do you want to know which way is north, Captain? `Cause I can tell you.
I'm very glad to hear it.  Welcome back, Pensacola.
Come on, Captain! Throw the ball! Let's see that arm!
I'm waiting for you to go long!
... And she leaves me on the deck, holding a football.

Fields.MenuText: Great. Now I'm talking to myself for no reason.
I was going to impress the hell out of you, you know!

Fields.DialogueText: I thought this *was* long for humans.
Pensacola, you're less than ten feet away.
What do I know? I've only ever caught a real football game on the radio.

Fields.MenuText: Stop screwing with me and go long.
Hey, you were the one who wanted to do this in the first place.
In fairness, I've never thrown one of these things either. Maybe ten feet is smart.

Fields.DialogueText: So intense!
And messing with you is part of the point!
See, never doubt the Belle's instincts, Captain.
Ma'am.
GAH! Stop sneaking up on me!
What's the word, Lieutenant?
We've made contact with authorities in Majuro, Captain. You can refer to my notes whenever, but the gist of it is that they've been under siege from the Morganas for the better part of three weeks.
They're crediting us with a full-blown rescue operation. And a joint American-Japanese science group should be en route to collect what left of the Morgana devices from Bikar Atoll.
... You can fill us in on the rest later, Lieutenant. Captain, I'm pretty sure we've got other American ships incoming.
All the way out here? Okay, tossing a football will wait - Lieutenant, notify the bridge, please. I'll be there in a couple of minutes.
Yes, Captain. I can throw the ball in the ocean as I go if you like.
Your problem is that you have no sense of fun, Justice. No appreciation of the joy that comes from physical exertion. You know the saying, "you don't know pleasure until you've run fifteen miles?"
Literally no one has ever said that.
Get going, Lieutenant.
Captain!
So... up for something new, Pensacola?
Sure. I mean, there's actually an upside to taking a nap and listening to you rattle on about civilian life, but-
Those were deep, personal confidences, I'll have you know.
Actually, I *do* know. I'll find a way to thank you sometime.
Anyway, let's go save the world. Or whatever it is we're doing. I'll see you on the bridge!
Oh, well. Next time.
Any word on that cruise ship we scuttled?
No. Everyone seems to be genuinely perplexed. Either it was dragged all the way from Japanese waters, or... I don't know what else.
Oh, well. At least the crew's used to it by now.
